title: Preseason Open Forum [day 1]

embed.description: What a time. You've read the sites, you've seen the devblogs , you've heard the announcements. Preseason is finally upon us. So what's on the docket for us this year? Well, to be frank, a little bit ofeverything. We're looking to make every game of League feels unique, and that means going the distance to make sure your decisions matter.

body:
You've survived the patch notes.

You've read the dev blogs.

We're going to be chilling in the dev corner this week to talk about any of the preseason changes coming in the patch. Hopefully by tomorrow you'll also have a few games under your belt.

Also: *you're not here to pose opinions as questions.*

And gold income got buffed. but AP characters can get up to 1000 ap while ad champs cant get THAT high

Could I please ask you for something important to me? Why Riot decided to force one specific team composition? Why there can be only one jungler? Why AD carry must be ranged? I understand that makes the game easier to balance and understand, but its 6 years already. Every change kinda forces players to play in an "imposed" manner.

I can answer you that. If you want 2 junglers, you need extremely good communication, which you can't get in soloq. Secondly, it is not viable to play with 2 junglers unless you lane swap and that also requires extremely good communication. AD doesn't have to be ranged, but meta is like that. Reason for this comes way before League of Legends and games in general: simply guy with a bow, if he have good arrows and is precise ( aka range champion), will kill a guy with a sword without a shield (aka assasins). The time melee champion, without gap close, needs to be close to range is enough for range to seriously wound him or kill him.
I'm sorry, but those were just examples. You know that in DotA you could take jungler or not, you could take hypercarry or not. LoL evolved from that game and lost diversity.

It was probably fated to evolve this way without stuff like pulling and champions that are good 1v3, to be honest. The trilane and offlane are cornerstones to DOTA's highly flexible meta, and without them you either have to run two duo lanes or put someone in the jungle, since the jungle can't really support two people farming it and you have nowhere else to put that person if you want a second solo laner getting full experience.

DOTA's full of weird stuff like pulling, stacking, denying, etc., which probably seemed minor to remove early on in League's lifespan ( which were likely removed to reduce the amount of knowledge needed to play effectively ) but ended up causing quite huge ripples in the game's evolution path, since they have far larger effects than they might seem ( if you try to 1v3 lane in League, you'll end up so far ahead in exp compared to your opponents; where in DOTA, a good duo lane can actually zone you and control the wave well enough to make it so you only get like 31 experience from your lane by the time they're both level 6. )

It's a hell of a discussion to get into, and I don't want to go too deep on it, but I often wonder about this debate and the inherent assumption that less structure is always better. At the end of the day, if a game has a clear win condition, something optimal will sort itself out, regardless of how many deviant paths it takes to get there (most tournaments sort themselves into an accepted 'stable meta' with 100% picks, like Gyro / Lesh / QoP at TI5 or GP / Morde at Worlds) . Personally speaking, I think structure in a game vs. open experimentation is a neutral concept at best, and both sides have their pros and cons.

Getting outside of the DotA vs. LoL debate, if you're playing a competitive game of dust2 and everyone buys an awp to cover long a and then they all get flashed and die to a weenie rush, nobody blames the 'enforced meta.' They just acknowledge that six dudes probably shouldn't all be sniping because there's an inherent understanding that in an FPS, there is a given degree of gun balance and structure.

For a while I think LoL tried very hard to say everyone can be a magical unicorn of cross-specializations and wacky team compositions, but I think in a world like that you're just entertaining novelty for the sake of novelty. League's groove is probably more in the realms of an organized sport like football or hockey. You can try putting a scrawny dude on defense, but you'd better have a damned good reason because the position in itself demands certain functionalities. There's still room for experimentation, but you fulfill a baseline criteria first so that everyone understands where you're deviating or experimenting. I think a system like that makes for an equally entertaining gameplay experience with a significantly more powerful spectating experience.

DotA, by the way, I love, and I enjoy the broad experimentation in it. Skadi combat Puck has always been my jam - but explaining the nuances of play, and the mental upkeep for how fast the game rotates from rat dota to deathball to everything else is an incredible barrier to entry. I'm glad I'm still able to keep up, but I do remember the hundreds of disorienting games I played where every time the rules, roles, and expectations would be upended because this time around Lina was going for a carry build.

Just my personal thoughts - we don't hear this as much these days but something to noodle on.

>It's a hell of a discussion to get into, and I don't want to go too deep on it, but I often wonder about this debate and the inherent assumption that less structure is always better. 

Would it be possible to give us a B option while still retaining structure?  I see you guys tried it with Morde and Kindred.  Is there any more design space like those guys that you can push into?

Oh absolutely. I love when we push design boundaries to allow champions to flourish in unique positions and roles without undermining the health of the game. If you bring a unique role to a unique position, there should be meaningful gains *and* meaningful tradeoffs for such a decision. If those tradeoffs are understood by both sides, I think that's fantastic design.

>I love when we push design boundaries to allow champions to flourish in unique positions and roles without undermining the health of the game.

You mean like the Mordekaiser travesty? Any plans on getting him the hell out of botlane? The boundaries were pushed, and he ended up in a position he wouldn't normally be in, so congratulations...however, let me be another of the many who have reminded Riot already; this wasn't wanted, it didn't work, this isn't healthy by any stretch of the imagination.

Edit: And know that this isn't me personally attacking you.

Holy jesus I get you're passionate but do you think this is a good way of setting up a constructive conversation?

I'm genuinely curious - when you write like this, what's your end goal? Shock me into submission? I don't think you would use this kind of approach with anyone in person, I don't understand why you think it's going to resonate on the internet.

I think people are just frustrated with his end state, and the lack of communication from CT. You're just the easiest person to blow steam at. I wouldn't take it personally, people are just mad. 

On topic, can you elaborate on the minion changes more? I see a lot of people concerned with them, and I'm also in that boat. Could this snowball games out of control really fast? What about if a team has an AFK?

This, of all the comments, is the one that makes you go 'woah hey that's not cool, we're trying to have a conversation here!'?

I've seen so much worse.
It's only because I have a history of openly criticizing and being vocally against Riot's design decisions.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Pwyff,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=GjE5bAFO,comment-id=00030001000000000001,timestamp=2015-11-10T23:37:01.553+0000)

They just acknowledge that six dudes probably shouldn't all be sniping because there's an inherent understanding that in an FPS, there is a given degree of gun balance and structure.

Fair enough. What may matter is tolerance to defeat. An intolerable experience leaving that repulsing feeling to a video game is not good, stating the obvious. It's likely qualified as fun if it's tolerable - _**"Why am I not enjoying LoL anymore?"**_. What I see is too many unnecessary game systems just messing everything up when they're not needed at all[**,**](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/ptf7T0AA-riots-not-being-fair-with-their-balancing?comment=0005) and up to average 45 minute game-times.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Pwyff,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=GjE5bAFO,comment-id=00030001000000000001,timestamp=2015-11-10T23:37:01.553+0000)
> League's groove is probably more in the realms of an organized sport like football or hockey. You can try putting a scrawny dude on defense, but you'd better have a damned good reason because the position in itself demands certain functionalities. There's still room for experimentation, but you fulfill a baseline criteria first so that everyone understands where you're deviating or experimenting. I think a system like that makes for an equally entertaining gameplay experience with a significantly more powerful spectating experience.

Yes. An idea allowing more than one 'kit design' (e.g. juggernaut or _new_) to at least perform **one of multiple secondary roles** by a greater selection of simplified 'equalizer' items sounds great .. and ambitious. The champion's kit will more or less still play the same but likely not as optimal in that secondary role compared to a champion who suits the role. Whichever way it goes, an optimal build for secondary roles will be discovered.

* How can an assassin opt to be fighter? [select recommended items] - **Sufficient and optimized. You can do it!**
* How can an assassin opt to be support? [select recommended items] - **Sufficient but not optimal.**
* How can an assassin opt to be tank? [select recommended items] - **Insufficient and not optimal. _Can_ try..**

Well.. I believe it's possible. The redevelopment from current system may be impossible .. but if 5.22 is going ahead, why not!?

I'll be honest - I know you're going for points here but you're drawing massive conclusions with very little support or structure. What sort of deep, *lasting*, fun design mechanics become exposed when a fighter can opt into an assassin pattern that is accessed purely by items? I understand the joy of experimentation and discovery, but does that meaningfully transfer into long-term satisfaction? Once you discover something once, does it become rote? Do you end up saying "Assassin Yi is garbage, only play Yi as a Fighter?"

I think DotA does an incredible job of encouraging experimentation and discovery. I think League has a far more structured "position strength" system where players can quickly compete and compare against others of their position - ie: battle of the mid laners like Faker vs. Bjergsen. You still get that with position 1-5 player comparisons in DotA, but often on a more holistic scale.

Ultimately, my argument comes to: why do we want to be DotA when DotA is an amazing DotA?

Ahh... The preseason, the time of the year to get funky and relearn league as we know it.

For me this means trying my hardest to get Mordekaiser working Solo as best as I can.
And behold, instead of change to the champion there are actually some changes benefitting the Murder Emperor.

**Runic Armor**
8% bonus to shields and healing?
Sign me up!
Do I hear the feint echo of "Huehuehue Always shield never die"?

**Hextech Gunblade**
Welp, since Trinity force has officially become way too gimpy for Morde we might see the return of Gunblade, seeing that he scales rather well with its AD and AP.
And the sweet, sweet 15% heal to ANY damage dealt is delectable.

But there are also some things that already make my skin crawl;
Bot lane will be Hell for Morde (But hey, I never liked him there anyways XD) with the reworked Marksmen having ways to deal with Morde quite easily.
Be it Graves bursting the tin can and counter pushing him into oblivion
Cait holding the guy hostage for 20 minutes 
Koggy recycling the metal man from a distance
Corki making him question his own niche as magic damage bot laner and so on.


I'll be keeping an eye on how things will unfold, it'll be very interesting to say the least.

How do you think these indirect changes will affect the (former) Master of Metal, The Iron Revenant, The HueKaiser?

Edit Numero Uno; Thoughts on maybe allowing Morde to enslave the Rift Herald?^^ 

Edit Numero Dos; I skimped through the preseason subsection about empowered AA's and Morde's Q wasn't listed.
Does this mean Blinds and such won't affect his (M)Ace of spades?

Certainly interesting. In the current live game, Mordekaiser's still quite successful on the bot lane, but I agree that a lot of these marksmen updates will make for a more challenging bot lane facing Morde.

Giving him the opportunity to enslave Rift would be neat, but I wonder if that just doubles down on the design concept. Dragon is about enabling a late-game win condition, Rift Herald is an early-game pushing threat. Enslaving Rift Herald would just mean getting an early game pushing threat on top of an early game pushing threat. Tres odd. Probably not something to do for the 'sake of doing it' though.

I'll ask about Morde Q - I recall there was a special conversation around him because it was considered a spell for certain purposes.

[edit] clarified: blinds should make his q now miss. Block and Evade only dodge the physical part.
Why is his Q treated as aoe spell although it is single target?
It's probably considered a multi-hit spell, not an AoE (which is closer to a DoT).
Reading through the minion and turret changes, basically nonstop split pushing ala Tryndamere seems like it could get out of hand pretty fast, any comments on this?

I do expect split pushing to be significantly stronger - that's on purpose. If it's out of hand or a dominant strategy, we'll deal with it, but we want it back at a much stronger level than in Season 5. It can be pretty frustrating to be on the receiving end of a dedicated split pusher, but the game needs the threat of those kinds of strategies to keep champion select from being all about who built the best deathball.

I want to talk about the changes to minions; they scare me. What worries me is that the subtle and interesting mini game of wave control will be damaged or worst case destroyed.

It's a fascinating and subtle thing to control the minion waves, and when done successful you can set up freezes to deny CS to enemy, or make large waves that damage side lanes as you do objectives. What worries me is that the changes to minions, make them auto push which makes setting up pushes and doing freezes much harder to control.

What is the intent behind the changes, and what is your thoughts about wave manipulation and the new system?
Why didn't Cass get mana buffs?
Why remove the passive from Tiamat and only leave it on Hydras?
bc they hate {{champion:121}} :''( (still waiting for a crying sticker...)
{{sticker:zombie-nunu-tears}}
How you plan to deal with Rift Herald and it's buffs if it shows extremely powerful in competitive play, especially in lane swap situations? -Radovan

Great question! We're going to be closely monitoring Rift Herald and what impact it really has on the map. If the team who gets the first Rift Herald wins 90% of their matches, that's definitely not a good thing. Or if we suddenly see every game having support and ADC go top to secure Rift Herald that's also not ideal. We want to make Rift Herald be a neutral objective that opens up strategic choice for teams, not become the must have objective. We can tackle this in many ways, whether that be tuning numbers on the buff, spawn timers, or tuning other objectives. Rest assured, if RH comes out too strong, we'll be quickly jumping on bringing it to a healthy place :). In the mean time we're super excited to see what kind of crazy strats evolve through the preseason and into next year.
What's the problem with bot lane moving to top?

its not a problem. its a sign that rift herald is too important of an objective for their goals. naturally the duo lane will always be within reach of the most valuable early game objective. i dont think riot would mind if duo mid became meta... in that case it would merely be a sign that the meta cares about both dragon and herald
This is exactly what I mean by us being excited to see what kind of strats come out in the following months :). Well put Maikokk.

Fair question Nitro, I wouldn't say anything is wrong with bot lane going top, but if every game turns into a flipped map I personally would believe that we made the Rift Herald buff too strong. With multiple win conditions on the map, we want there to be a balance in how teams weigh their importance and strategize around that.

Kind of concerned about the minion and tower changes, can you explain the reasoning behind these and what you hope they will accomplish?
Also this bail out mechanic just sounds like a bad change...
Does Windspeaker's Blessing work with heimerdinger´s passive? I´m wondering since Heimerdinger is the only one to grant allied champions Health regeneration

Why did you remove the Pink jungle item? That was a popular item that was used a lot, and was my go-to jungle item for the sustain and faster jungle clear. I used it on EVERYONE.
Why would you remove it? Put it back please, there was no reason and this will make my jungling a lot more shitty because I'm used to jungling with it.

I'm super disappointed that tanks aren't getting any proper love or shiny new toys this preseason. They truly feel like a forgotten subset of the game over the last few months while everything else is trying new and awesome things.

The only thing that left a lasting impression on me was the cindermeta this year. And that wasn't a fun new toy, or an exciting addition to a role. It just sucked because it was a ball of damage that made you guys beat the class back down with the nerfbat because of badly tuned numbers.

I want to see new avenues for something less threatening than an Amumu ult, and much much harder to peel or lock down than a Nasus. I want old Garen back. I want old Udyr back. I want Mundo with some kind of real lockdown in exchange for his overbearing sit-on-you-with-damage dive pattern.

I want a slippery tank who can wade into the enemy team with defensive steroids and low damage, and wade back out with tenacity and movespeed steroids. I don't want to be a juggernaut who races the carry's HP to zero. I want to provide pressure and zoning to enemy carries with my body and presence, and NOT my cc or damage. Garen and Udyr appeal so strongly because Garen could walk in and out with Q mobility and W tenacity and damage reduction, and Udyr could soak so much damage with spammable shields without committing.

I still try to make this fantasy a thing in League, but over the last few months I've lost so many tools for it in item changes. Randuins, Thornmail, and Frozen Heart have each taken sizeable hits to their lategame effectiveness, and the replacements I'm being shown like Gage, Plate, and Titanic are so woefully lacking in defensive stats because they have this worthless damage, or cooldown based utility attached. I can't go anywhere anytime with those items, and my old standbys are rusting, especially considering all the new tools for ADCs to eat me with.

I understand that the mobility and survivability I demand for my fantasy playstyle will come with tradeoffs. I'm prepared to do limited damage and forego powerful hardCC. I *loved* the old Garen, running around, regenning, and throwing an impactful silence now and then. I wish there were an option for me in this game.

I think "Also: you're not here to pose opinions as questions."

implies "you're not here to pose opinions and not questions" in general
That sounds like your opinion... ;3

Not sure if I mentioned it in THIS thread yet or not, but, while I'm not really concerned it's going to ruin the game, I really wonder why pink trinket was removed from the game.  I remember Xypherous said something about just not thinking it was needed, but I don't see why it can't be an OPTION.


Also, are you guys at Riot at all concerned that the raw power of Executioner's Calling/Mortal Reminder Is going to marginalize Morellonomicon?

Finally, Deathfire Touch vs. Thunderlord's Decree.  For the most part I thought probe were feeling Deathfire is the stronger mastery, so why does Thunderlord's have an internal cooldown but not Deathfire?


Oh... And why don't the flasks turn into cookies/biscuits?  (And I refuse to call Hunter's Potion anything other than the Jungle Canteen)

I have some minor concerns about the new Tracker's Knife for the jungle. Considering the jungler is one of the two members of the team most expected to control vision due to their roaming, and since every lane is now gonna have 2 ward charges by default on their trinket (which makes it trickier to find the unwarded route to gank from), I feel like the Tracker's Knife will become the mandatory jungle item so that you can pick up a red trinket to sweep wards.

Is this at all a concern for the team as well? Or is the expectation that, with the overall number of wards reduced by not being able to buy them anymore, that the red trinket will be overall weaker by enough that the minor smite buffs from Skirmisher's Sabre/Stalker's Blade will actually be able to compete effectively?

It's something we'll certainly be watching, but {{item:3706}} and {{item:3715}} are both very powerful, and base yellow trinkets have 2 charges - there are other strong options. I think it'll be ok, but if it isn't, we'll certainly react. We want it to be a valid option but we don't want it to stomp out the other two.

It seems like the changes to turrets, gold and minions are going to largely benefit snowballing. In fact, it seems like you made a ton of changes so that the game doesn't go much further than the 30 minute mark, and that if one team gets a good early game, the other has much less chances of coming back.
I'm not sure if I'm interpretating this in the right way. But what do you have to say about this? Do you think that the snowball potential is indeed higher? If it gets out of control, how will you counter it - will you remove some of the implemented features? (for instance, the minion damage seems pretty devastating right now - take 3 towers and suddenly every lane is pushing hard by itself)

Are you gonna do something about the state of Assassins or will they stay useless for all eternity? Surely you must've realized that the countless nerfs, releases of anti-Assassin champions and itemization changes makes them pretty much unplayable.

they actually HAVE talked about this a bit:

The marksman changes aren't straight buffs across the board, but they are generally buffs, so with marksman becoming even more valuable, assassins will be more useful just because there are more high-priority targets worthy of deleting.
Is there any way that  masteries can be "exportable", something like the itemsets? I dont want to do +10 masteries page for every acc that i own
